What's our solution?

An effective solution to solve traffic congestion issues is to utilize public transport and carpool. Public transportation including using buses, trains, and also streetcars. Carpooling is when multiple people share a car to go to a certain destination. Carpooling is especially convenient because you and a friend or family member can travel together, and that will be one less car on the road. Whether it be to work, school, or even to buy groceries; carpooling is a very simple way to reduce the number of cars on the road. There are many benefits to using public transportation and carpooling.

Health benefits

Taking public transport has a positive impact on health as it leads to an incidental increase in physical activity. According to the article, “Physical activity levels in American and Japanese men from the era-jump study and associations with metabolic syndrome”, the daily average steps for the citizens of Pittsburgh were approximately 7900, while the daily average for citizens of Kusatsu were approximately 9100 (Sagawa et al., 2020). A huge factor in the difference between Japanese and American daily step counts is Japanese people’s use of public transport. According to the Statistical Handbook of Japan 2021 “the Japan Railways (JR) group reported 9.50 billion passengers... Railways other than JR reported 15.69 billion passengers…[and commercial] buses transported 4.53 billion passengers in fiscal 2019” (Statistics Bureau, Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, n.d.). According to the article “Physical Activity Associated with Public Transport Use—A Review and Modelling of Potential Benefits” from the MDPI, “In the US, 29 percent of those who use transit were physically active for 30 minutes or more each day (and considered as sufficiently active), solely by walking to and from public transit stops” (Rissel et al., 2012). Using public transport can help not only relieve traffic issues, but can also allow people to become stronger through incidental exercise.

Environmental benefits

Using public transportation can drastically decrease the amount of CO2 emissions in the atmosphere. According to the Kansas City Area Transportation Authority “A single person who switches from a 20-mile [commute] alone by car to existing public transportation, can reduce their annual CO2 emissions by 20 pounds per day, or more than 48,000 pounds in a year” (KCATA, n.d.). This will not only positively impact the environment by aiding in reducing global warming, but also humans and animals since the air will be less polluted.

Safety

Using public transportation is an easy way to reduce the chances of accidents. According to a study by the American Public Transport Association, as explained by the Rail Passengers Association, “taking public transit, such as trains and buses, decreases the chances of an individual being in an accident by more than 90 percent when compared to driving” (2016). The website further explains that “According to the U.S. Department of Transportation, more than 35,000 people were killed on U.S. roads in 2015, an increase of 7.2 percent from 2014…” and “Taking a bus or train allows commuters to multitask, sleep or avoid driving drunk” (Rail Passengers Association, 2016). Especially for teens and elderly who might have trouble driving, it is important to rely more on public transportation in order to stay safe while travelling.

Save time and money

Many people do not realize the amount of money wasted on fuel when going through traffic; just because someone is stopped in traffic does not mean they are saving fuel. Using public transport instead of cars to run errands or go to nearby locations will not only help reduce congestion, but it will also save you money. According to the Kansas City Area Transportation Authority in an article titled Environmental Benefits of Public Transit they state that “In 2011, U.S. public transportation use saved 865 million hours in travel time. Without public transportation, congestion costs in 2011 would have risen by nearly $21 billion from $121 billion to $142 billion in 498 urban areas” (KCATA, n.d.). The article goes on to explain that “Public transportation use saves the U.S. the equivalent of 4.2 billion gallons of gasoline annually — and more than 11 million gallons of gasoline per day” (KCATA, n.d.). Using buses and trains can help save a lot of money as you cut back on weekly or bi-weekly fuel costs.
